articles.author: Maryn McKenna
articles.title: The Challenge of Covid-19 Vaccines for the Immunosuppressed
articles.description: Recent studies find transplant patients and immune-suppressed people who get the shot don’t make many antibodies. But that research is just beginning.
articles.content: In March, the group published the first data from those sign-ups: Among 436 transplant recipients, only 17 percent showed detectable antibodies after one dose of the Pfizer or Moderna vaccines. That … [+4154 chars]

articles.author: Matt Simon
articles.title: Peanut the Waiter Robot Is Proof That Your Job Is Safe
articles.description: Restaurants are struggling to hire people, so one Jersey Shore grill employed a machine. It confirms that humans remain indispensable.
articles.content: Robots also lack the kind of intelligence, manual dexterity, and people skills that any good cook, host, or server relies on to keep their diners happy. Can Peanut talk down a customer whos irate bec… [+3985 chars]

articles.author: Grant Currin
articles.title: Volunteers Digitized Centuries of Handwritten Rain Data
articles.description: As the UK went into lockdown, 16,000 volunteers put their spare time to good use, transcribing 350 years of archival records for use by modern climate scientists.

articles.author: Jennifer Clare Ball
articles.title: Lakes Are Losing Oxygen—and Their Inhabitants Are in Danger
articles.description: Hundreds of temperate lakes around the world are showing trends toward anoxia, becoming warmer, murkier, and less hospitable to cold-water species.

articles.author: Matt Simon
articles.title: Northern Farms Are Releasing Massive Amounts of Carbon
articles.description: Humans have been draining peatlands to grow crops for centuries. It's a huge, underestimated source of greenhouse gas, scientists say.
